title: Hanukkah
time_location: All Day (until January 2)
description:
Also known as the Festival of Lights, Hanukkah is an eight-day Jewish holiday celebrating the re-dedication of the Second Temple in Jerusalem in the second century A.D. It is often celebrated with the lighting of menorah candles, as well as traditional foods, games, and gifts.
Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs.

title: Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives
time_location:
All Day (until June 1)
Hunt Library, Fourth Floor
description:
Settlement, industrialization, urbanization and redevelopment have each left a profound mark on the region’s built environment. The architecture bears testimony to the forces that shaped it, but buildings can only tell part of the stories. The histories of their conception, design, and construction are contained in the drawings and other documents shared between clients, architects, and contractors. These architectural records document an irretrievable past (for buildings demolished or left unbuilt), facilitate the preservation and reuse of extant buildings, and inform our understanding of our surroundings.

For the past 40 years, the Architecture Archives collections at Carnegie Mellon University have documented thousands of projects and the work of hundreds of designers. Records have been obtained from architects and their firms, families, property owners, and governments. This wide diversity of materials—preliminary sketches, renderings, specifications, photographs, publications and architectural models—helps piece together the rich history of Pittsburgh and the region.
Visit the exhibit website to learn more.

title: Kwanzaa
time_location: All Day (until January 1)
description:
An African-American and Pan-African holiday celebrating family, community and culture, Kwanzaa is a secular observance with some religious participation. Each day of Kwanzaa celebrates a different life virtue.
Carnegie Mellon University intentionally fosters a community where all voices and views are heard and respected, which includes religious backgrounds and spiritual beliefs.

title: Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s
time_location:
All Day (until July 11)
Hunt Library Gallery
description:
Carnegie Mellon University entered the 80s as a well-respected regional university, but President Richard Cyert’s vision at the start of the decade would help turn CMU into an international leader in innovation, technology and the arts.
Before long, robotics, computer software and the Internet were integral parts of the campus. In 1984, Terregator—the “world’s first rugged, capable, autonomous outdoor navigation robot”—was completing its field testing at CMU. In 1985, the university began working with Apple founder Steve Jobs to develop part of the Mach operating system that ran on his NeXT computer workstation. In 1986, CMU launched the Andrew system, a joint endeavor between IBM and CMU to create the world’s first university-wide computer network and file system.
This growth led the university to develop a comprehensive video marketing plan that attracted the attention of high school guidance counselors, parents, and students from around the country.
By the decade’s end, the university experience had transformed in ways few could have imagined.
Learn more at https://library.cmu.edu/about/exhibits/cmu-1980s

title: New Year’s Day
time_location: All Day
description: January 1 is a Federal Holiday, marking the first day of the new year according to the Gregorian calendar.

time_location: All Day
description: Though it is called by many names, on January 6, Christians of different traditions celebrate the visit of the three magi to worship Jesus Christ. The details of how this holy day is honored vary among Christian traditions and cultures, including Eastern Orthodoxy.

title: MORSE-ls of Inspiration: Crafting Your Go-to Message in the New Year
time_location:
Noon - 1:30 p.m.
Center for Student Diversity & Inclusion, Cohon University Center, Lower Level 75
description:
Morse code has historically been used to send important messages to specific audiences. Take the time to think about an important message you would like to craft for yourself this year. Then, work with us as we create a unique combination of beads and bars to feature your one-of-a-kind message on a Morse code bracelet just for you! We will also provide a light lunch.
We hope to see you there! Please register to let us know if you will attend.

title: Mentoring Undergraduate Researchers: An Institute for Graduate Students and Postdoctoral Fellows
time_location:
9 a.m. to Noon January 9 - 10, 2025
Tepper Building 1308
description:
This two-day institute will prepare graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to design a project and mentor undergraduate students in research. Participants will leave with a toolkit of strategies to answer the following questions:
What is inclusive and effective mentoring?
How is mentoring similar to and different from teaching?
How do you negotiate your own identity while mentoring?
How can you help undergraduate researchers develop habits of mind and skills?
How do you determine appropriate research goals and scope projects for individual students?
Register at https://seminars.eberly.cmu.edu/.
Presented by the Eberly Center and the Office for Undergraduate Research & Scholar Development

title: Building Bridges: Campus Edition
time_location:
5 p.m.
William Pitt Union, Lower Lounge, 3959 Fifth Ave.
description:
Join us for a special conversation with Carnegie Mellon University and University of Pittsburgh affiliates about how Pittsburghers can build bridges and care for the community in this time. Palestinian peacemaker Aziz Abu Sarah and Israeli peacemaker Maoz Inon have both experienced immeasurable tragedies growing up in the region, yet they choose reconciliation over revenge. They have been traveling across the globe to share their message of hope and will now bring their learnings and experiences to Pittsburgh.
Attendance is limited to CMU and Pitt faculty, staff and students.
Advanced registration is required.

title: Leveraging Clean Energy for National Defense
time_location:
5 - 6 p.m.
Grand Room, Posner Hall (340)
description:
Author Harry Krejsa, CMIST’s Director of Studies, will discuss findings and policy recommendations at the intersection of clean technology, national security and U.S.-China relations, offering strategies to modernize infrastructure, enhance cybersecurity, and embrace clean energy innovations.
Key topics Include:
The role of clean energy in countering cyber threats, particularly from the People’s Republic of China.
Modernizing U.S. infrastructure with secure, digitally-native technologies.
Strategic recommendations for aligning clean energy and national security goals.
About the Speaker
Harry Krejsa is the Director of Studies at the Carnegie Mellon Institute for Strategy & Technology. He joined Carnegie Mellon from the White House’s Office of the National Cyber Director, where he led development of the 2023 National Cybersecurity Strategy, established national clean energy security priorities, and represented the U.S. government in technology security consultations with foreign partners and the global private sector. Krejsa previously worked at the intersection of technology, industrial strategy, and U.S.-China competition for the Department of Defense, the Cyberspace Solarium Commission, and the Center for a New American Security.
Register

title: Tatiana Bilbao in Conversation with Raymund Ryan and Stefan Gruber: From the Living Room to the Commons
time_location:
3 - 4:30 p.m.
Carnegie Museum of Art, Heinz Architectural Center
description:
If the architecture of our homes provides a primary form of care, the urban fabric of our cities shapes our social relations and collective identities. How does architecture define the relationship between the individual, community and society? How can we design neighborhoods and cities that foster a sense of place and belonging? And how do the domestic spaces we inhabit add up to more than the sum of the parts that constitute a city?
Open to the public.
Carnegie Mellon Architecture’s Public Programs series is generously sponsored by the Alan H. Rider Distinguished Visiting Lecturer in Architecture Fund, the William Finglass Practice Lecture Series Fund, and the Vetter Memorial Lecture Fund.

title: Conocimiento: Personal Storytelling featuring a National Day of Racial Healing experience
time_location:
4:30 - 6:30 p.m.
Connan Room, Cohon University Center
description:
Conocimiento means knowledge and wisdom, to be conscious and to become aware. It is a practice that builds community and deepens relationships through group discussions and personal growth.
A critical component of racial equity and racial healing work, the Conocimiento principle: emphasizes the necessity of consciously creating community within a group, heightens the potential for personal growth and shared action, helps foster and cultivate a culture of belonging.
Conocimiento is not an icebreaker, but an engagement practice that encourages people to bring their full selves into the room.

title: Martin Luther King, Jr. Day

title: Here to Stay: Celebrating 40 Years at the Architecture Archives
time_location:
All Day (until June 1)
Hunt Library, Fourth Floor
description:
Settlement, industrialization, urbanization and redevelopment have each left a profound mark on the region’s built environment. The architecture bears testimony to the forces that shaped it, but buildings can only tell part of the stories. The histories of their conception, design, and construction are contained in the drawings and other documents shared between clients, architects, and contractors. These architectural records document an irretrievable past (for buildings demolished or left unbuilt), facilitate the preservation and reuse of extant buildings, and inform our understanding of our surroundings.

For the past 40 years, the Architecture Archives collections at Carnegie Mellon University have documented thousands of projects and the work of hundreds of designers. Records have been obtained from architects and their firms, families, property owners, and governments. This wide diversity of materials—preliminary sketches, renderings, specifications, photographs, publications and architectural models—helps piece together the rich history of Pittsburgh and the region.
Visit the exhibit website to learn more.

title: Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s
time_location:
All Day (until July 11)
Hunt Library Gallery
description:
Carnegie Mellon University entered the 80s as a well-respected regional university, but President Richard Cyert’s vision at the start of the decade would help turn CMU into an international leader in innovation, technology and the arts.
Before long, robotics, computer software and the Internet were integral parts of the campus. In 1984, Terregator—the “world’s first rugged, capable, autonomous outdoor navigation robot”—was completing its field testing at CMU. In 1985, the university began working with Apple founder Steve Jobs to develop part of the Mach operating system that ran on his NeXT computer workstation. In 1986, CMU launched the Andrew system, a joint endeavor between IBM and CMU to create the world’s first university-wide computer network and file system.
This growth led the university to develop a comprehensive video marketing plan that attracted the attention of high school guidance counselors, parents, and students from around the country.
By the decade’s end, the university experience had transformed in ways few could have imagined.
Learn more at https://library.cmu.edu/about/exhibits/cmu-1980s

title: Archiving in Conversation: An Archivist, a Historian, and an Architect
time_location:
5:30 - 7 p.m.
Margaret Morrison Carnegie Hall, Room 103
description:
Archivists have evolved from historians managing research materials to professionals across various sectors. Different archives serve distinct purposes: academic archives support research, community archives preserve local heritage, and radical archives use artistic and social justice approaches to protect cultural memory.
What is an archive? How do archives shape our understanding of knowledge, histories, cultures, and societies? How are digital methods implicated in archival work, access, and erasure? How might archives put our memories at risk? How do archivists, historians and designers use and question “archives?” How might you begin archiving personal, community, and cultural memories? How might we archive the digital?
Moderated by Vernelle A. A. Noel
Assistant Professor of Computational Design
The Lucian and Rita Caste Assistant Professor in Architecture and Urban Design
Supported by the Frank-Ratchye STUDIO for Creative Inquiry and the Sylvia and David Steiner Speaker Series
Open to the public.
RSVP is required.

title: George Guida Lecture: Towards a New AI Architecture: Future of Practice
time_location:
5:30 - 7 p.m.
Kresge Theater, College of Fine Arts
description:
Learning Objectives:
Understand the fundamental concepts and definitions associated with AI and its applications in architectural practice
Explore practical applications of AI in design, across design stages, and learn how these could be integrated into architectural education and practice
Analyze the impact of AI on professional practice, including potential changes in workflows, efficiency, and values
Discuss the ethical considerations and regulatory impacts of AI in architecture, ensuring responsible and ethical use of AI
This is an-person event; the recording will be made available on Vimeo.
Open to the public.
RSVP
Carnegie Mellon Architecture’s Public Programs series is generously sponsored by the Alan H. Rider Distinguished Visiting Lecturer in Architecture Fund, the William Finglass Practice Lecture Series Fund, and the Vetter Memorial Lecture Fund.

title: Hacking4Humanity
time_location: Noon to 5 p.m. Jan. 24 - Feb. 7, 2025
description:
H4H is open to any undergraduate or graduate student in the Pittsburgh area; participants may register/compete individually or in teams of up to four people.

Participants approach the problem of online hate by selecting one of the two tracks and create/develop an innovative intervention to mitigate the problem of online hate:
Technology (apps, robotics, designs, etc)
Policy (federal, local, regional, corporate, etc.)
The top entries in each track - technology and policy – will each receive $500! Second place participants will receive $200!
Registration is required! To learn more or register, visit www.hacking4humanity.online/

title: Libraries Workshop: Data Communication: Data Storytelling
time_location:
9 - 10 a.m.
Online
description:
When working with data, the ways we communicate about or discuss analysis is as important as the act of research itself. A large part of being able to effectively use data is to understand what stories are contained within data sets, and what information may play a key role in analysis. 
In this workshop, we will go over strategies to develop research questions tied to specific data sets, core elements of data that may lead to successful and fruitful analysis, and how to use both data and results from analysis to communicate ideas to academic and public audiences.
Open to the public.
Registration is required. Registrants will receive a link to the workshop the day prior.

Participants will learn strategies to create safer, more inclusive environments and how to actively oppose hate while supporting those affected.
This event is part of CMU’s Combating Hate series, hosted by the Office of the Vice Provost for Diversity, Equity and Inclusion and Chief Diversity Officer.
Register now

title: Influence Without Arms: The New Logic of Nuclear Deterrence, with Matthew Fuhrmann
time_location:
5 - 6:30 p.m.
Grand Room, Posner Hall 340
description:
Join the Carnegie Mellon Institute for Strategy & Technology (CMIST) for an insightful discussion of Matthew Fuhrmann’s most recent book, Influence Without Arms: The New Logic of Nuclear Deterrence.
How does nuclear technology influence international relations? While many books focus on countries armed with nuclear weapons, this volume puts the spotlight on those that have the technology to build nuclear bombs but choose not to. These weapons-capable countries, such as Brazil, Germany, and Japan, have what is known as nuclear latency, and they shape world politics in important ways.
Offering a definitive account of nuclear latency, Dr. Fuhrmann navigates a critical yet poorly understood issue. He identifies global trends, explains why countries obtain nuclear latency, and analyzes its consequences for international security.
Matthew Fuhrmann is the Cullen-McFadden Professor of Political Science at Texas A&M University. He has been a Visiting Professor at Yale University (2023-24), Visiting Associate Professor at Stanford University (2016-17), Stanton Nuclear Security Fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations (2010-11), and Research Fellow at Harvard University’s Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs (2007-08). He was named an Andrew Carnegie Fellow in 2016 by the Carnegie Corporation of New York. His research and teaching focus on international security issues with an emphasis on nuclear weapons, diplomacy and bargaining, and alliance politics. He is the author of three books, including Influence Without Arms: The New Logic of Nuclear Deterrence (Cambridge University Press, 2024) and Nuclear Weapons and Coercive Diplomacy (Cambridge University Press, 2017, with Todd S. Sechser). His articles are published in journals such as American Journal of Political Science, Journal of Politics, British Journal of Political Science, International Organization, International Security, and International Studies Quarterly. His research has been mentioned in media outlets such as CNN, The New York Times, The New Yorker, and NPR.
Register for the event.

title: Libraries Workshop: Geographic Optimization with QGIS: Route Planning
time_location:
10:30 a.m. - Noon
Sorrells Library Den, Wean Hall Fourth Floor
description:
Participants will learn to utilize QGIS tools for route planning, including data filtering, spatial queries and geoprocessing algorithms, to identify optimal routes based on various criteria such as distance, travel time or cost. The workshop will guide attendees through designing linear optimization workflows within QGIS to solve complex route planning problems.
By the end of the session, participants will be able to leverage QGIS to perform data-driven route optimization, improving their spatial decision-making and problem-solving skills in geographic contexts.
This workshop is designed for beginners and intermediates. You can download the QGIS software on the QGIS.org website. We recommend installing the Long-Term Version.
Please bring a laptop and have the software installed prior to the workshop.
Open to the public.
Registration is required.
